articles.headline: Death Penalty Foes Split Over Taking Issue to Supreme Court
articles.snippet: A justice’s dissent may have invited a challenge by opponents of capital punishment, but one group of opponents is eager to bring a case and another is much more cautious.
articles.abstract: A justice’s dissent may have invited a challenge by opponents of capital punishment, but one group of opponents is eager to bring a case and another is much more cautious.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the long legal struggle against the death penalty, the future has in some ways never looked brighter.

articles.headline: Honda Drops Takata as U.S. Issues Huge Fine Over Airbags
articles.snippet: Besides Honda’s decision, United States traffic safety officials fined Takata an amount that could go as high as $200 million.
articles.abstract: Besides Honda’s decision, United States traffic safety officials fined Takata an amount that could go as high as $200 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: Honda Motor Company on Tuesday dropped the embattled manufacturer Takata as its airbag supplier, concluding that the company, its longtime partner, had “misrepresented and manipulated test data.”
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Danielle Ivory

articles.headline: VW Reveals It Misstated Emissions of Gas Cars
articles.snippet: The company said it had underreported the carbon dioxide emitted by 800,000 diesel- and some gasoline-powered cars, and would set aside $2.2 billion to cover the cost of the problem.
articles.abstract: The company said it had underreported the carbon dioxide emitted by 800,000 diesel- and some gasoline-powered cars, and would set aside $2.2 billion to cover the cost of the problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: Volkswagen’s pollution problems took a costly new turn on Tuesday when the company said it had understated emissions of carbon dioxide, a greenhouse gas, for about 800,000 of its vehicles sold in Europe, and overstated the cars’ fuel economy.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Graham Bowley

articles.headline: School vs. Society in America’s Failing Students
articles.snippet: In tests, American students fall behind their peers in many countries, but adjusting for demography and access to resources gives a different picture.
articles.abstract: In tests, American students fall behind their peers in many countries, but adjusting for demography and access to resources gives a different picture.
articles.lead_paragraph: Here’s the good news: American schools may not be as bad as we have been led to believe.

articles.headline: China, Taiwan and a Meeting After 66 Years
articles.snippet: President Ma Ying-jeou of Taiwan is to confer with President Xi Jinping of China in Singapore on Saturday, according to statements from both.
articles.abstract: President Ma Ying-jeou of Taiwan is to confer with President Xi Jinping of China in Singapore on Saturday, according to statements from both.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — President Xi Jinping of China and Taiwan’s president, Ma Ying-jeou, will meet on Saturday in Singapore, the first such meeting since before the Chinese Communist revolution of 1949 and the retreat of the Chinese Nationalists across the Taiwan Strait.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Austin Ramzy

articles.headline: Smaller Overseas Entrepreneurs Find China Too Frustrating
articles.snippet: While China beckons with cheaper labor and a huge market, it often frustrates with bureaucracy, corruption and a byzantine legal system.
articles.abstract: While China beckons with cheaper labor and a huge market, it often frustrates with bureaucracy, corruption and a byzantine legal system.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — With the blessing of local officials, Amir Porat, an Israeli entrepreneur, set up a surgical supply factory in 2013 in China’s coastal Jiangsu Province, training workers and taking orders. All he needed to start production was $250,000 of specially designed molding equipment from Israel.

articles.headline: China Burns Much More Coal Than Reported, Complicating Climate Talks
articles.snippet: China has been using up to 17 percent more coal a year than reported. By some estimates, that means almost a billion more tons of carbon dioxide released annually.
articles.abstract: China has been using up to 17 percent more coal a year than reported. By some estimates, that means almost a billion more tons of carbon dioxide released annually.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China, the world’s leading emitter of greenhouse gases from coal, has been burning up to 17 percent more coal a year than the government previously disclosed, according to newly released data. The finding could complicate the already difficult efforts to limit global warming.

articles.headline: Success Metrics Questioned in School Program Funded by Goldman
articles.snippet: Early-education experts are questioning the metrics used to measure the success of a public-private preschool program in Utah in which Goldman Sachs has invested.
articles.abstract: Early-education experts are questioning the metrics used to measure the success of a public-private preschool program in Utah in which Goldman Sachs has invested.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was, in the vernacular of corporate America, a win-win: a bond that paid for preschool for underprivileged children in Utah while also making money for investors.

articles.headline: Houston Voters Reject Broad Anti-Discrimination Ordinance
articles.snippet: In one of the most closely watched referendums in the country, voters repealed an anti-discrimination ordinance, handing gay rights supporters a stinging defeat.
articles.abstract: In one of the most closely watched referendums in the country, voters repealed an anti-discrimination ordinance, handing gay rights supporters a stinging defeat.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — A yearlong battle over gay and transgender rights that turned into a costly, ugly war of words between this city’s lesbian mayor and social conservatives ended Tuesday as voters easily repealed an anti-discrimination ordinance that had attracted attention from the White House, sports figures and Hollywood celebrities.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and Mitch Smith

articles.headline: In Honda’s Rebuke of Takata, a Rare Move for Business Partners in Japan
articles.snippet: Companies in Japan form longstanding relationships that extend down manufacturing supply chains, but such ties can have downsides.
articles.abstract: Companies in Japan form longstanding relationships that extend down manufacturing supply chains, but such ties can have downsides.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — When a car manufacturer publicly questions the honesty of a business partner that supplies it with vital safety equipment, it is a sure sign that the relationship is in trouble.
